column4: Im using Ubuntu 6.06 I need read and write access fro my windows NTFS hard drives. Is ntfs-3g the best option and is writing to ntfs partitions really safe to do with Linux and third party apps?? <--------
you're asking for trouble if you want that
Really? Some people over here earlier recommended that for me...
safe useage: use a FAT32 partition for read/writing in Windows and Linux. NTFS writing could screw up your Windows partition. Remember that NTFS is not an open format
you can write to a NTFS partition using Linux, but I wouldn't call it safe. Use it on your own risk. Don't come crying here if you have data corruption ;-)
Thanks, maybe I'll change my NTFS partitions to FAT32, though that makes XP a lil slower. How Fast linux writes to FAT32?
FAT32 is commonly supported, it just works. Tip: there are several Windows tools with which you can convert NTFS to FAT32 without data loss
Im using Jetico Bestcrypt. It's good it has Blowfish-448 encryption. It's very strong
Jetico Bestcrypt is free for Linux, but I guess it's not open source
there are also windows tools that can read from linux partitions and you can read data from your windows ntfs partition in linux. So read/read usually works fine ;)
Yeah reading works fine but what I really need is a good write access to my windows partitions. Otherwise I might as well use XP.
then you should really use FAT32 or completely switch to Ubuntu :)
I change NTFS to FAT32 and see how it work <-------
you don't need to use '<---', it's annoying
I recommend minimal of 3GB for linux, but if possible >10GB, then you have some 'play space' left
